results.adx_keywords: Fertilizer;Shortages;Waste Materials and Disposal;Recycling of Waste Materials;Agriculture and Farming;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Rich Earth Institute;Niger;United States
results.title: Meet the Peecyclers. Their Idea to Help Farmers Is No. 1.
results.abstract: A shortage of chemical fertilizer, worsened by the war in Ukraine, has growers desperate. It just so happens that human urine has the very nutrients that crops need.

media.caption: A funnel for collecting urine in the home of Kate Lucy and Jon Sellers in Brattleboro, Vt.
media.copyright: John Tully for The New York Times

results.title: ‘The Old Man’ Brought Jeff Bridges to TV. John Lithgow Had No Advice.
results.abstract: The two award-winning actors had never worked together before this brooding FX thriller came along. Who knew the journey would become so existential?

media.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Real Estate and Housing (Residential);Gardens and Gardening;Flowers and Plants;Lawns;Content Type: Service;Grass;Sustainable Living
results.title: Yes, You Can Do Better Than the Great American Lawn
results.abstract: There are any number of ecologically friendly alternatives to that lawn you’re so proud of — and they look nice, too. Here’s how to start slowly.

media.caption: Low-growing wild strawberry (Fragaria virginiana) is one of the ecological horticulturist Daniel Jaffe Wilder’s favorite native lawn alternatives. It can withstand foot traffic, and the plants produce small, edible fruit.

results.adx_keywords: Movies;Elderly;Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide;Content Type: Personal Profile;Cannes International Film Festival;Hayakawa, Chie;Japan
results.title: A Filmmaker Imagines a Japan Where the Elderly Volunteer to Die
results.abstract: The premise for Chie Hayakawa’s film, “Plan 75,” is shocking: a government push to euthanize the elderly. In a rapidly aging society, some also wonder: Is the movie prescient?

media.caption: Chie Hayakawa in Tokyo. Her new film “Plan 75” takes on one of the biggest elephants in the room in Japan: the challenges of dealing with the world’s oldest society.
media.copyright: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Abortion;Jews and Judaism;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision);Florida
results.title: Synagogue Sues Florida, Saying Abortion Restrictions Violate Religious Freedoms
results.abstract: A South Florida congregation said that under Jewish law, abortion “is required if necessary to protect the health, mental or physical well-being” of a pregnant woman.

media.caption: Rabbi Barry Silver of Congregation L’Dor Va-Dor said it is a violation of Jewish law to forbid a woman from having an abortion if she deems it esssential for her physical or mental health.

results.title: This Elegant Trunk Holds a Complete Mahjong Set
results.abstract: Louis Vuitton’s six-drawer vanity contains 144 carved and hand-painted tiles.

media.caption: The French house’s latest Vanity Mahjong Trunk features a six-drawer vanity and hand-painted tiles backed in walnut. Price on request; (866) 884-8866.
media.copyright: Still life by Antoine Henault. Set design by Mélodie Balan

results.title: F.D.A. Authorizes Moderna and Pfizer Covid Vaccines for Youngest Children
results.abstract: A recommendation from the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention would be the final step before doses are rolled out for the roughly 20 million children younger than 5.

results.adx_keywords: Private Spaceflight;Labor and Jobs;Musk, Elon;Shotwell, Gwynne;Space Exploration Technologies Corp
results.title: SpaceX Said to Fire Employees Involved in Letter Rebuking Elon Musk
results.abstract: In an email, Gwynne Shotwell, SpaceX’s president, said the letter had made other employees “feel uncomfortable, intimidated and bullied.”

media.caption: A letter sent by some SpaceX employees said the public behavior and tweeting of Elon Musk, above, was “a frequent source of distraction and embarrassment.”

results.adx_keywords: Floods;Yellowstone National Park;Montana
results.title: Yellowstone Towns Had Big Summer Plans Until Floods Struck
results.abstract: The deluge of rain has shut down a park entrance that is a lifeline for neighboring tourist communities. “Seventy-five percent of my business has been cut off at the knees,” one shop owner said.

media.caption: Receding floodwaters flowing past North Entrance Road, which connects Yellowstone National Park and Gardiner, Mont. Parts of the road were washed away by recent floods.

results.adx_keywords: Virtual Reality (Computers);Children and Childhood;Therapy and Rehabilitation;Autism;Telemedicine
results.title: Can Virtual Reality Help Autistic Children Navigate the Real World?
results.abstract: One company, Floreo, is hoping their tools will lead the way, despite some criticisms from autism self-advocates.

media.caption: Floreo, founded by Vijay Ravindran, formerly of Amazon, is developing virtual reality lessons designed to help behavioral therapists, speech therapists, special educators and parents who work with autistic children. Here, Mr. Ravindran’s son, uses his VR headset.
media.copyright: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Hate Crimes;Chinese-Americans;Asian-Americans;Discrimination;Race and Ethnicity;audio-negative-sad;Chin, Vincent;Detroit (Mich)
results.title: Decades After Infamous Beating Death, Recent Attacks Haunt Asian Americans
results.abstract: Vincent Chin, a Chinese immigrant, was beaten to death after being pursued by two white Detroit autoworkers in 1982. On the 40th anniversary of his death, many hear frightening echoes.

media.caption: Anthony Lee working on a tribute painting of Vincent Chin, a Chinese American who was killed during a period of resentment against the rise of Japanese carmakers.
media.copyright: Sarah Rice for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Art;Nineteen Hundred Seventies;Hannah, Duncan (1952- );Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: Duncan Hannah, Artist and ’70s Chronicler, Dies at 69
results.abstract: He immersed himself in the wild New York scene of Warhol and CBGB, then emerged in the ’80s as a respected painter.

media.caption: Duncan Hannah in 2016 at the opening of a show of his work at New Release, a gallery in Chinatown. His paintings owed a debt to Edward Hopper and Winslow Homer but also had a vaguely eerie quality.
media.copyright: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Sociology;Women's Rights;Deaths (Obituaries);Smith, Dorothy E (1926-2022)
results.title: Dorothy E. Smith, Groundbreaker in Feminist Sociology, Dies at 95
results.abstract: Starting in the 1960s, she sought to re-center her discipline on the experiences of women, people of color and other marginalized groups.

media.caption: Dorothy E. Smith in 2018. She argued that while conventional sociology claims to be the disinterested pursuit of objective truth, it is in fact encoded with ideologies that see the male experience as universal.

results.adx_keywords: Handbags and Purses;Relocation of Business;Black People;Content Type: Personal Profile;Artbag Creations Inc;New York City;Coral Springs (Fla)
results.title: Who Will Repair Their Birkins Now?
results.abstract: Artbag, the Madison Avenue shop that socialites and celebrities have trusted to restore their chic handbags for 90 years, is closing.

media.copyright: Elianel Clinton for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Cats;Animal Behavior;Insects;your-feed-animals;your-feed-science;iScience (Journal)
results.title: Chewed and Rolled: How Cats Make the Most of Their Catnip High
results.abstract: A new study finds that the feline reaction to catnip and silver vine helps to stave off mosquitoes and other bloodsucking insects.

media.caption: The blossoming catnip plant was found to release 2,000 percent more bug-repelling iridoids when damaged by cats.
